bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Laura Armistead Carter, August 20, 1928

div1.p: Hanson attempts to answer Carter's questions about various medical references and describes his work in Florida on malaria outbreaks.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Laura Armistead Carter, August 20, 1928
div1.opener:
IN GOD WE TRUST.
Bureau of Communicable Diseases
DR. F. A. BRINK, DIRECTOR
FLORIDA
STATE BOARD OF HEALTH
B. L. Arms, M. D., State Health Officer
Executive Office, Jacksonville
THE BOARD
-----
HON. CHAS. H. MANN, PRESIDENT
JACKSONVILLE
H. MASON SMITH, M. D.
TAMPA
WM. D. NOBLES, M. D.
PENSACOLA
Marianna, Fla.
August 20, 1928.
My dear Laura:
div1.p:
Your letter of July 28, 1928, (better underscore the year)
reached me a short time ago, in fact several days, but I was so d---- hot
that I could not think clearly enough to write intelligently to a
celebrity like you.

You seem to have almost run through the catalogue of ills,
and I hope that you have had enough of flu and things for a while. I too
have experimented a little in that line since I last saw you,-had an
attack of four lobe pneumonia in Miami last March, so you see I am no
“piker” when it comes to having things.

I dont know that I can give you very much help about the
quotations or references for the book. Most of the references were from
personal communications, letters which I wrote your father from Peru and
Colombia. I went over some of these with Frost last fall when I was in
Baltimore one day.
Your, " P.8.Hanson Henry (1921) a personal letter.

" P. 10 " " (1922) Re lower limit of
aegypti feeding, was observed in
Pacasmayo by Dr. Ricardo Mendosa, when
he was bitten by an aegypti, the ther-
mometer registering 17C. This too if I
remember correctly was a personal communication. I have none of
my papers with me, and can not say whether this was mentioned oin
the general report, written at the close of the campaign.

" P.29. " The reference to aegypti found at
?/ Ica, is from the report made by L.H. Dunn and Dr. Caballero when I
sent them for a survey of the coast of Peru, south of Lima, from
Lima to Arequpipa.

I am not certain about Sir Rupert Boyce reference, but
have an idea I saw something to that effect in the report of the
Previous Yellow Fever Commission, the one composed largely of British,
my recollection is that I saw it in the first volume. There is a
copy of this in the Lagos Office.

I can not tell you which of the Pasteur Commission
reports, cites a case of the transmission of infection to progeny,
except that it is from the work of the Commission in Brazil. All
notes of this kind are with my library at home. Some of them reached
Sioux City after I came on to Florida.

I gave a talk before the Medical Society at Ancon
Hospital in 1921, which was reported and published in the proceedings
of the Canal Zone Medical Society about the end of 1921 or the first
part of 1922.

I cant give you any information about Goedldi's statement (19031)
regarding the breeding of Stegomyia in gutters (street gutters).
We found them in gutters In Barranquilla, but I felt that it was more
a case of their having been come there by accident, such as the
emptying of a barrel of water in which there were larvae, and they
naturally continued their development. We had a similar instance in
Bucaramanga, close to a house where breeding was found.

I am sorry that I am so disappointing in the help you
hoped I might be able to render.

Since the first of the year I have been working in the
capacity of Field Medical Officer, in the Bureau of Communicable
Diseases, State Board of Health of Florida, and have found it both
instructive and interesting, if not highly remunerative. It has about
paid expenses which was as much as I expected when I came down. There
are some pretty good malaria problems to work on among the backwoods
people here in West Florida. Malaria is one of the big factors in the
ill health and poverty of most of the country people in this part of
the state.

How long I shal continue here in this work I dont know. The
Surgeon General (U.S.P.H.S.) has suggested a possibility of going to
Singapore, but that is rather uncertain so far.

With all good wishes, and high regards to Frost when you
see him, I am
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Henry Hanson Official address,
State Board of Health,
Pensacola, Fla.
